results.title: ‘Scream’ Review: Kill Me Again, Again
results.abstract: Neither a remake nor a sequel, this tired retread can’t move forward for looking back.

multimedia.caption: Jenna Ortega, right, with Ghostface in “Scream.”

results.title: ‘Belle’ Review: Soaring and Singing Over the Online Rainbow
results.abstract: In this gorgeous anime, a high school student journeys into a virtual world and finds herself amid cute, kooky and menacing fellow users.

multimedia.caption: Magical U: A scene from “Belle,” directed by Mamoru Hosoda.

results.title: One Indelible Scene: When a Woman Takes the Wheel in ‘Licorice Pizza’
results.abstract: After letting Alana Haim and her character drift and idle, Paul Thomas Anderson gives you a reason to cheer: “Hardcore, hardcore Alana!”

multimedia.caption: Bradley Cooper, left, Cooper Hoffman and Alana Haim in the truck in “Licorice Pizza.”

results.title: One Indelible Scene: When the Show Must Go on in ‘Drive My Car’
results.abstract: Through a staging of “Uncle Vanya,” the director Ryusuke Hamaguchi creates an intimacy for his characters that lets the artifice of cinema fall away.

multimedia.caption: Park Yurim and Hidetoshi Nishijima in “Drive My Car.”

results.title: And the 2022 Oscar Nominees Should Be …
results.abstract: The nominations will be announced Feb. 8. Here’s what our critics wish academy voters would put on their ballots.
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott

results.title: ‘Scream’ at 25: How Meta Can You Get?
results.abstract: After 25 years, the influence of Wes Craven’s self-aware slasher still looms large, both for the imitators that followed and the backlash it set off.
des_facet: I Know What You Did Last Summer (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Courteney Cox, left, Jamie Kennedy and Neve Campbell in the original, Wes Craven-directed “Scream.”

results.title: The Visions of Penélope Cruz
results.abstract: She already felt a mystical connection with the director Pedro Almodóvar. For their seventh collaboration, “Parallel Mothers,” she gave her all, even collapsing after one scene.

multimedia.caption: “When I look back, I don’t remember it as suffering,” Penélope Cruz said of playing Janis in “Parallel Mothers,” because “for me, she was alive.”
multimedia.copyright: Camila Falquez for The New York Times

results.title: We’re Going to Talk About ‘Bruno,’ Yes, Yes, Yes
results.abstract: “We Don’t Talk About Bruno” from “Encanto” is a surprise chart topper and TikTok darling. Here’s how Disney created its biggest smash since “Let It Go.”

multimedia.caption: Dolores (voiced by Adassa) and Mirabel (Stephanie Beatriz) duet on “We Don’t Talk About Bruno.”

results.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a family-friendly Belgian drama about immigrants, a Mexican class-conflict thriller and a South Indian superhero tale.

multimedia.caption: Bebel Tshiani Baloji in “Binti.”

results.title: Alec Baldwin Turns Over His Phone in ‘Rust’ Investigation
results.abstract: Detectives investigating the actor’s fatal shooting of a cinematographer on a film set in New Mexico had gotten a search warrant for the phone nearly a month ago.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: New Mexico detectives investigating Alec Baldwin’s fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” will get data from the actor’s iPhone, under an agreement he made with investigators, his lawyer said.

results.title: ‘There’s Not Just One Type of Porn’: Erika Lust’s Alternative Vision
results.abstract: The Swedish moviemaker thinks pornography can create a society that sees sexuality as myriad and joyful, and where women’s pleasure matters.

results.title: Mommy Is Going Away for a While
results.abstract: The antiheroine of the moment, in movies like “The Lost Daughter” and novels like “I Love You but I’ve Chosen Darkness,” commits the mother’s ultimate sin: abandoning her children.
results.byline: By Amanda Hess and Liana Finck
des_facet: I Love You but I've Chosen Darkness (Book)

results.title: Bosnian Film Director Is Vilified in Serbia and ‘Disobedient’ at Home
results.abstract: Jasmila Zbanic, who won best director for “Quo Vadis, Aida?,” insists on blaming individuals, not ethnic groups, for atrocities committed as Yugoslavia imploded, a stance that can anger all sides.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: The film director Jasmila Zbanic in Sarajevo, Bosnia, this month.
multimedia.copyright: Damir Sagolj for The New York Times

results.title: Alec Baldwin Will Turn in Phone to Investigators This Week, Lawyer Says
results.abstract: The sheriff’s office in Santa Fe said nearly a month had elapsed since a search warrant was issued for the phone, but it had not yet been surrendered.

multimedia.caption: Alec Baldwin’s lawyer said his cellphone would soon be handed over to officials investigating the shooting death of a cinematographer. In an ABC News interview, Baldwin said he was not responsible for the killing.
multimedia.copyright: Jeffrey Neira/ABC News, via Associated Press

results.title: ‘Who We Are: A Chronicle of Racism in America’ Review: Social Studies
results.abstract: In a documentary constructed around a lecture from 2018, the lawyer Jeffery Robinson presents a persuasive look at United States history.

multimedia.caption: Jeffery Robinson in the documentary “Who We Are: A Chronicle of Racism in America.”

results.title: Animation That’s More Than Kids’ Stuff
results.abstract: A handful of animated features gaining attention this awards season take a more mature approach.

multimedia.caption: A scene from Mamoru Hosoda’s film “Belle.”

results.title: ‘Hotel Transylvania: Transformania’ Review: Another Monster Mash
results.abstract: The plot, about a crystal-powered ray gun that can turn monsters into humans, seems to acknowledge the need to goose its characters out of their inertia.

multimedia.caption: Wanda (Molly Shannon), Wayne (Steve Buscemi),  Murray (Keegan-Michael Key), Mavis (Selena Gomez), Blobby and Ericka (Kathryn Hahn) in “Hotel Transylvania: Transformania.”

results.title: ‘A Cops and Robbers Story’ Review: Keep Your Enemies Closer
results.abstract: This documentary follows a police officer who rose through the ranks while concealing his criminal past.

multimedia.caption: Corey Pegues eventually reached the level of commanding officer in the New York City Police Department.

results.title: ‘Why Is We Americans?’ Review: A Family Synonymous With Newark
results.abstract: This documentary looks at Amiri Baraka and his loved ones, who have played a vital role in arts and politics in their city and beyond for generations.

multimedia.caption: Pictured in the documentary “Why Is We Americans?,” Amina and Amiri Baraka in 1970, with children. Standing, Wanda, and seated on floor, Vera, Wilson (Amina’s daughters from her first marriage); and on their parents’ laps, baby Ras and Obalaji Baraka.

results.title: ‘The Pink Cloud’ Review: Love in Lockdown
results.abstract: Iuli Gerbase’s first feature film reflects a funhouse-mirror image of our present lives.

multimedia.caption: Renata de Lélis in “The Pink Cloud.”

results.title: ‘Brazen’ Review: Not So Novel
results.abstract: A prolific crime novelist teams up with a hunky homicide detective to track down a killer in this painfully formulaic Netflix murder mystery.

multimedia.caption: Alyssa Milano in “Brazen.”

results.title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Sues Supplier of Ammunition and Guns for Film Set
results.abstract: The lawsuit accuses the supplier of contributing boxes of ammunition that were represented as containing only inert dummy rounds but that included live rounds.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: The set of “Rust” in Santa Fe County, N.M. in October 2021.

results.title: It Started With a Kiss. Then Film Scholars Found More.
results.abstract: MoMA’s series on film restorations, To Save and Project, is highlighting Black cinema, including what may be the earliest example of African American intimacy onscreen.

multimedia.caption: “Something Good — Negro Kiss,” starring Gertie Brown and Saint Suttle, was released in 1898.

results.title: ‘Dear Mother’ Review: Mamarazzi
results.abstract: Laurent Lafitte directs and stars in this fast-paced French comedy about a man forced to reconnect with his mother.

multimedia.caption: Laurent Lafitte and Karin Viard in “Dear Mother.”

results.title: Don’t Sleep on These 6 Performances During Awards Season
results.abstract: As various nominating groups unveil their choices, these impressive turns have been largely overlooked. But there’s still time to rectify that, academy voters!
des_facet: The Worst Person in the World (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top left, Colman Domingo, Ruth Negga, Jessie Buckley, Olga Merediz, Renate Reinsve and Ben Affleck.
multimedia.copyright: Clockwise from top left: Anna Kooris/A24 ; Netflix; Netflix; Warner Bros.; Kasper Tuxen/Neon, via Associated Press; Jessica Forde/20th Century Studios

results.title: Jonny Greenwood: First Radiohead, Now Orchestras and Film
results.abstract: Scoring films like “The Power of the Dog” and “Spencer,” he has become a major composer, his concert music fueling his soundtracks.

multimedia.caption: Jonny Greenwood’s film scores at first seemed like a side hustle, something to keep him occupied between albums and tours. But they have blossomed into a true career.

results.title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a personal essay on tobacco, an experimental look at pieces of the Berlin Wall and a chronicle of a revolt in Wukan, China.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the documentary “Lost Course,” about a revolt in Wukan, China in 2011.

results.title: SAG Award Nominations 2022: The Complete List, Snubs and Surprises
results.abstract: “Being the Ricardos” hit big, but some likely contenders, including Kristen Stewart, were overlooked.
des_facet: Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Nicole Kidman, left, and Javier Bardem were both nominated for their performances in “Being the Ricardos.”

results.title: Poitier and Bogdanovich: The Defiant Ones
results.abstract: Sidney Poitier and Peter Bogdanovich were geniuses of the Hollywood system who, with great success and frustration, worked to transform it in the same era.
results.byline: By A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis

multimedia.caption: Peter Bogdanovich in 1973 and Sidney Poitier circa 1965. Both were directing films in the same post-studio era.
multimedia.copyright: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images, left, and Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

results.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
results.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

multimedia.caption: The Jets, led by Mike Faist, center, stake out territory on actual city streets.

results.title: ‘Encanto’ Soundtrack Ousts Adele From No. 1
results.abstract: The album of music from the latest Disney animated film climbs to the top of the Billboard 200 after first arriving in November.

multimedia.caption: The “Encanto” soundtrack, with songs by Lin-Manuel Miranda that draw on salsa and hip-hop, initially arrived at No. 197.

results.title: Golden Globes 2022: ‘Succession’ and ‘Power of the Dog’ Take Top Honors
results.abstract: With the Hollywood Foreign Press Association mired in controversy,   the event was devoid of stars or cameras. Winners were announced via Twitter, and social media had a field day.

multimedia.caption: Statuettes were ready at the Beverly Hilton last week.

results.title: Quiet Awards Season Has Hollywood Uneasy
results.abstract: Audiences remain reluctant to return to theaters. And the kinds of movies that used to rely on the sheen of awards to attract moviegoers now find themselves in peril.

multimedia.copyright: Illustration by Delcan & Co.; Photograph by Peter Dazeley/Getty Images

results.title: Max Julien, Star of a Cult Blaxploitation Film, Dies at 88
results.abstract: Black audiences flocked to see him in “The Mack,” and generations of cinephiles have paid homage to his star turn, his smooth delivery and his extraordinary costumes.

multimedia.caption: The actor and screenwriter Max Julien in the title role of the 1973 film “The Mack.” The story of an ex-con who becomes a pimp, it was based on a story written in prison by an actual convict.
